cheatsheetvideos.quote: Alexa shares with us how she went in for her Class A permit and decided to get her Hazmat endorsement as a bonus!
Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: What does blocking cargo do?
questions.answerA: Holds the cargo in a large box
questions.answerB: Prevents cargo from sliding in transit
questions.answerC: Prevent others from buying the cargo
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are used to prevent cargo from shifting in transit.

questions.question: Which of the following is a good rule to follow when making a turn?
questions.answerB: Use your arms to get the attention of other drivers.
questions.answerC: Turn off your turn signal before entering the turn to avoid confusing other drivers.
questions.explanation: Signal well in advance of a turn so drivers behind you are aware of your intentions. Keep the signal on throughout the turn and turn it off once the turn is complete.

questions.question: When checking the engine compartment:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should not be engaged.
questions.answerD: The gearshift should be in first gear.
questions.explanation: Before inspecting the engine compartment, make sure that the parking brakes are on and/or the wheels are chocked. Check the engine compartment before entering the cab and starting the engine.

questions.question: Testing positive for any amount of alcohol while still below the legal limit will result in a driver being placed out-of-service for 24 hours.
questions.explanation: If you are found to have any detectable amount of alcohol in your system, but are still below the legal limit of 0.04 percent, you will be placed out-of-service for 24 hours. It is both illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: A stopped bus:
questions.answerA: Is not a cause for concern since it is stopped.
questions.answerB: Is only a concern if passengers are exiting the bus.
questions.answerC: Is a concern whether or not passengers are visible.
questions.explanation: You should always exercise caution when driving near a stopped bus. There could be passengers in the vicinity and the bus may either prevent them from seeing you or you from seeing them.

questions.question: Always perform the steps of a pre-trip inspection in the same order each time because:
questions.answerA: You will be less likely to forget something.
questions.answerB: You will have more time to complete the inspection.
questions.explanation: Completing the steps of a vehicle inspection in the same order before every trip aids in learning what the proper steps are. Additionally, you be less likely to forget a step when going through the checklist in a prescribed order.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerB: Should be repaired, but do not need to be repaired immediately.
questions.explanation: The suspension system is responsible for supporting a vehicle, supporting its load, and keeping its axles in place. When inspecting your vehicle, check for damaged or missing spring hangers, spring leaves, shock absorbers, u-bolts, and frame members. Broken parts in the suspension system are extremely dangerous.

questions.question: When starting your vehicle, the coolant temperature should:
questions.answerC: Quickly jump from low to high.
questions.explanation: Watch the gauges in your vehicle before starting a trip. After starting your vehicle's engine, the coolant temperature should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: States verify that a CDL or CLP driver has only one such license by:
questions.answerA: Making phone calls to surrounding states.
questions.answerB: Using a computerized system that links all states.
questions.explanation: All U.S. states share information about CDL and CLP licenses in a computerized database. If you apply for a license in one state, a state will check this database to verify that you do not already have one such license in another state.

questions.question: When using a fire extinguisher on a fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Get as close to the fire as possible.
questions.answerB: Stay as far away from the fire as possible.
questions.answerC: Aim the extinguisher at the top of the flames.
questions.answerD: Aim the fire extinguisher at the ground about two feet away from the fire.
questions.explanation: When using a fire extinguisher, you should stay as far away from the flames as possible and aim at the base of the fire.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you will be evaluated on your lane usage. Which of the following is an example of poor lane usage?
questions.answerA: Not driving over curbs or sidewalks
questions.answerC: Driving in the leftmost lane if more than one driving lane is available
questions.answerD: Finishing a right turn in the rightmost lane
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, make sure you do not put your vehicle over curbs, sidewalks, or lane markings. Stop behind stop lines, crosswalks, or stop signs. On multiple-lane roads, complete turns in the proper lane. Always move to or remain in the rightmost lane, unless the lane is blocked.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, a look is when:
questions.answerA: A driver checks the gauges on their instrument panel.
questions.answerB: A driver checks their blind spots.
questions.answerC: A driver walks to the back of their vehicle to check its position.
questions.explanation: A driver uses a look when they open their door, leave their seated position, and walk to the back of the vehicle to check its position. During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerB: Only occurs as a result of people who are physically doing something while driving.
questions.answerC: Can occur as a result of mental activities, such as daydreaming.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerA: Can damage parts of a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Is necessary to warm up parts of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged to improve a vehicle's gas mileage.
questions.explanation: Always speed up smoothly and gradually so that your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: When approaching your vehicle as part of a pre-trip inspection, seeing fresh oil underneath the vehicle is:
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle, you should check under the vehicle for fresh oil, coolant, grease, or fuel leaks. Spotting any of these before a trip is a cause for concern.

questions.question: When starting a trip while transporting a load, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Stop to check on the cargo within the first 50 miles of the trip.
questions.answerB: Drive faster than usual to test the security of the load.
questions.answerC: Only use the side mirrors to check on the cargo.
questions.answerD: Not recheck the cargo if it was secured properly before starting the trip.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles thereafter.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tank.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and compressor oil from the air tank.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do so can cause damage. Manually operated drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: Mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.answerC: When you are standing next to the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Mirrors should be checked prior to the beginning of a trip. On a vehicle with a trailer, mirror adjustment can only be checked accurately if the connected trailer is straight.

questions.question: To avoid a hazard, you:
questions.answerA: Should always come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: May need to swerve your vehicle out of the way.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the best way to avoid a hazard. If there is not enough space for you to stop to avoid coming into contact with the hazard, swerving out of the way may be your safest option.

questions.question: When should a turn signal be canceled by a driver?
questions.explanation: If your vehicle does not have self-canceling turn signals, be sure to cancel your turn signal after completing a turn.

questions.question: If a CMV driver operates a CMV with a detectable blood alcohol concentration (BAC) that is lower than 0.04 percent, they will be:
questions.answerC: Required to drive at speeds below 55 mph.
questions.explanation: If you are found to be operating a CMV with any detectable amount of alcohol in your system, but you are still below the legal limit of 0.04 percent, you will be placed out-of-service for 24 hours. It is both illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: Headache racks:
questions.answerB: Help protect the driver from the cargo.
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect the driver from cargo moving in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.answerD: Used to stop the vehicle in normal driving.
questions.explanation: The parking brake should be applied every time you park your vehicle.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should:
questions.explanation: If someone is tailgating you, it is a good idea to open up the space ahead of your vehicle to make it easier for the driver to pass you. Increasing your speed is not a good idea because the driver may continue to tailgate you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: Traction is important in:
questions.explanation: You will not be able to brake or steer your vehicle without adequate traction. Ensure that your tires are in proper working condition before beginning a trip.

questions.question: A tank endorsement is:
questions.answerC: Required to transport both liquids and gases.
questions.explanation: Subject to certain conditions, a tank endorsement is required to operate a tank vehicle that is used to haul either liquids or gases.

questions.question: Mirrors should be:
questions.answerC: Checked only if there is a reason to suspect a problem.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should regularly check your mirrors, both to be aware of traffic and to check for problems on your own vehicle.

questions.question: Parts of an exhaust system should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting an exhaust system, you should verify that parts of the system are not loose, broken, or missing. The system's parts must be properly mounted and should not be rubbing against moving parts of the vehicle.

questions.question: What is the Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR)?
questions.answerA: The maximum permitted total weight of a vehicle and its cargo
questions.answerB: The minimum permitted weight of a trailer
questions.answerC: The maximum permitted weight of a trailer and its contents
questions.answerD: The maximum permitted weight of only a tractor
questions.explanation: The Gross Vehicle Weight (GVW) is the total weight of a single vehicle plus its load. The Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) is the maximum combined weight of a vehicle and its cargo that is permitted and specified by the manufacturer.

questions.question: Retreaded tires:
questions.answerA: May be used on any part of a bus.
questions.answerB: May be used on the front of a bus.
questions.answerC: May be used on the rear of a bus.
questions.answerD: May never be used on a bus.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are prohibited from use on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: When alley docking, you should first:
questions.answerA: Position your vehicle directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerB: Back up directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerC: Stop parallel to the outer boundary of the alley.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.explanation: Always speed up smoothly and gradually so that your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: When driving down a steep grade, your brakes may fade. What happens if brakes fade?
questions.answerD: They work differently from front to back.
questions.explanation: If you use your brakes too much when traveling on a steep downgrade, they may overheat and become less effective. To avoid causing your brakes to overheat on a steep hill, you should rely on engine braking.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indicator of when to upshift?
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: What is the average driver’s reaction time?
questions.answerC: Between three-quarters of a second and one second
questions.explanation: The average driver has a reaction time of between three-quarters of a second and one second.

questions.question: A commercial motor vehicle driver:
questions.answerA: May use any cell phone while driving.
questions.answerB: May only use a hands-free cell phone while driving, if permitted.
questions.answerC: May only use a cell phone while driving on rural roads.
questions.explanation: If you choose to use a mobile phone while operating a CMV, you may only use a hands-free mobile phone that is located close to you. However, even a hands-free mobile phone can be a dangerous distraction while driving. Make sure you are aware of all cell phone laws in the state in which you are driving.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerA: Is caused only by physical distractions.
questions.answerB: Will be increased by pre-programming radio stations.
questions.answerC: Can be prevented by avoiding conversation with others.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should increase your speed to shake the other driver.
questions.explanation: It is a bad idea to increase your speed if another driver is following you too closely. Speeding up may result in the driver continuing to tailgate you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: When alley docking, your vehicle should be parked:
questions.answerA: With the front bumper on top of the front boundary line.
questions.answerB: With the rear wheels over the rear boundary line.
questions.answerC: Straight within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.answerD: At an angle within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: When approaching a vehicle for a pre-trip inspection, a driver should look under the vehicle:
questions.answerA: To see if the vehicle is on an incline.
questions.answerB: To see if there are any fresh fluids on the ground.
questions.answerC: To see if the vehicle is in a parking spot.
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle before an inspection, make note of its general condition and ensure that it is not damaged or leaning. Look under the vehicle for fresh leaks of oil, grease, or fuel. Check around the vehicle for hazards to movement, such as people, other vehicles, or low-hanging wires or tree limbs.

questions.question: When you leave your vehicle, you should:
questions.answerC: Leave the keys in the ignition.
questions.explanation: The parking brake should be applied when leaving your vehicle.

questions.question: How long should it take for oil pressure to reach a normal level when starting a vehicle?
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the oil pressure should come up to a normal level within seconds. Do not operate a vehicle if it has oil pressure that is low, dropping, or fluctuating.

questions.question: If pulled over on the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Use the taillights to alert other motorists.
questions.answerC: Keep your lights off to avoid distracting other drivers.
questions.answerD: Set out items from the cab to warn motorists.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, you should turn on your emergency flashers and place the appropriate warning signals to warn other drivers.

questions.question: Before starting down a hill, you should:
questions.explanation: Always downshift before beginning to drive downhill. Take the hill at a speed that does not require you to overuse your brakes.

questions.question: If air pressure drops to a level between ____, a visual low pressure warning signal should have already activated.
questions.explanation: A visual low pressure warning signal should activate before air pressure drops to a level between 55 and 75 psi. This signal could be a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a potential effect of drinking alcohol then driving?
questions.explanation: Driving errors that may be caused by alcohol-induced impairment include straddling lanes; quick, jerky starts; failure to signal or use lights; running stop signs and red lights; and improper passing. A driver's reaction time will become poor when they are under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: You should not use your mirrors.
questions.answerC: You should not use your turn signals.
questions.explanation: Always use your turn signals and check your mirrors when changing lanes.

questions.question: If a truck is equipped, a trailer brake hand valve can be used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.
questions.explanation: If a tractor-trailer is so equipped, the trailer brake hand valve can be used to stop the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.

questions.question: On a leaf spring:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's suspension, verify that leaf springs do not have missing or broken leaves. If at least one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing, the vehicle will be put out-of-service until the defect is fixed.

questions.question: The minimum tread depth of all major grooves on tires that are not on the front of a CMV should be a minimum of:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires, and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch on the other tires. Tires on the same vehicle should all be the same size.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Has a single air brake system, but uses two sets of controls.
questions.answerB: Has one air brake system for each side of the truck.
questions.answerC: Has two brakes for each wheel.
questions.answerD: Has two separate air brake systems, but uses a single set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems that use a single set of brake controls. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles. The other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: A suspension system:
questions.answerB: Uses pressurized water to support the load.
questions.explanation: Suspension systems receive weight capacity ratings, given by the manufacturers.

questions.question: A cargo cover that flaps in transit:
questions.answerB: Allows air to get to the cargo to keep it cool.
questions.explanation: Cargo covers should not flap in the wind. A flapping cover could tear loose entirely, exposing the cargo, and potentially blocking your view or the view of other drivers.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the driver.
questions.answerC: Challenge the driver to a road race.
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, the most important thing to do is get out of their way, if possible. Do not provoke the driver by challenging them or making eye contact, and do not let yourself be provoked by rude gestures they might make.

questions.question: When alley docking, your vehicle should be parked:
questions.answerA: With the front bumper on top of the front boundary line.
questions.answerB: With the rear wheels over the rear boundary line.
questions.answerC: Straight within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.answerD: At an angle within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerA: Are not safe to be used.
questions.answerB: Are acceptable to be used on tires on the rear of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable to be used only when carrying a heavy load.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs should never be used.

questions.question: When driving through a work zone, you should:
questions.answerD: Steer with one hand to keep the other hand free.
questions.explanation: In work zones, you should observe posted speed limits. Slow down if road or weather conditions are poor, and slow down even further if workers are near the roadway.

questions.question: Saving money is the primary reason for conducting a pre-trip inspection.
questions.explanation: The primary reason to inspect your vehicle before every trip is to ensure your safety and the safety of other road users.

questions.question: Who is responsible for the safe operation of a vehicle?
questions.explanation: The person driving a vehicle is responsible for its safe operation. Be sure to perform routine vehicle inspections before operating a commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: Hydroplaning:
questions.answerB: Usually happens when vehicles are traveling faster than 65 mph.
questions.answerC: Can occur with a minimal amount of water on the roadway.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be a large amount of water on the road for this to occur.

questions.question: To avoid a hazard:
questions.answerA: You should always steer to the left.
questions.answerB: You may be able to drive onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: You should steer sharply in one direction.
questions.explanation: In some emergencies, the best strategy for avoiding a hazard may be to drive onto the shoulder. Most shoulders are strong enough to support the weight of a large vehicle.

questions.question: A broken exhaust system can allow poisonous gas to enter the cab.
questions.explanation: A broken exhaust system is extremely hazardous because it can permit poisonous fumes to enter the vehicle's cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: While driving, your mirrors:
questions.answerB: Should only be used when changing lanes.
questions.explanation: While driving, regular mirror checks are essential to remaining aware of the traffic around you. Mirrors are also essential to helping you spot possible problems on your own vehicle.

questions.question: When traveling down a long downgrade, you should brake by:
questions.answerB: Mostly using the brakes and downshifting occasionally.
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, you should use the braking effect of your engine as the principal way of controlling your speed. Save your brakes for additional slowing or stopping that may be required by road or traffic conditions.

questions.question: Some air brake systems introduce alcohol into the system to:
questions.answerA: Make the brakes work without squeaking.
questions.answerB: Prevent ice from forming in the brake system.
questions.answerC: Prevent people from breathing the air from the system.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems contain an alcohol evaporator. An evaporator introduces alcohol into the system to help inhibit the formation of ice in cold weather.

questions.question: A distracted driver:
questions.answerC: Is usually aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerD: Is a good person to follow.
questions.explanation: Driving while distracted may result in slowed perception, delayed decision-making, and improper actions. Watch for distracted drivers and avoid them, when possible.

questions.question: Headlights:
questions.answerA: Are not usually necessary when driving at night.
questions.answerB: Provide better light than the sun.
questions.answerC: Should be on the high beam setting whenever possible.
questions.answerD: Should always be on the high beam setting.
questions.explanation: To improve visibility, you should use high beam headlights at night where it is safe and legal to do so. However, the glare from high beam lights can blind other drivers. You should dim your lights to their low beam setting when driving within 500 feet of an approaching vehicle.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in an air brake system is releasing air:
questions.answerA: You should not be concerned as this is a normal process.
questions.answerB: There is something wrong with the brakes.
questions.explanation: The safety relief valve in an air brake system releases air if necessary to prevent pressure in the system from becoming too high. If the valve starts releasing air, there is something wrong. Have a mechanic fix the problem.

questions.question: When checking your windshield wiper blades, the blades should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check the wiper blades for damage, stiff rubber, and proper securement.

questions.question: Driving at night is:
questions.answerA: Safer than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Just as safe as driving during the day.
questions.answerC: More dangerous than driving during the day.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day because hazards become more difficult to see in the dark.

questions.question: If being tailgated, you should open up your following distance.
questions.explanation: If someone is tailgating you, it is a good idea to open up the space ahead of your vehicle to make it easier for the driver to pass you. Increasing your speed is not a good idea because the driver may continue to tailgate you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: Regulations regarding commercial vehicle weight and load securement may vary from state to state. Regarding these regulations:
questions.answerA: The laws of the state where the trip originated take precedence.
questions.answerB: The laws of the state in which the vehicle is physically located take precedence.
questions.answerC: The driver can choose which state’s laws to follow.
questions.explanation: Federal, state, and local regulations governing commercial vehicle loads vary from place to place. Be sure that you are always aware of the laws for the state in which you are driving.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated while driving a large vehicle, do all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: If you find yourself being tailgated by another driver, you should increase your following distance and avoid making quick moves. Increasing your speed may only result in the other driver continuing to tailgate you at a higher speed. Do not turn on your taillights or flash your brake lights at the other driver.

questions.question: The leading factor resulting in death and injury in work zones is:
questions.explanation: The leading cause of injury and death in roadway work zones is excessive speed by passing drivers. Lower your speed when driving through a work zone.

questions.question: What does ABS do?
questions.answerB: Prevent the air compressor from overheating
questions.answerC: Prevent the front brakes from being used on ice
questions.answerD: Prevent the brakes from being used if downshifting would be more effective
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent wheels from locking up during hard applications of the brakes, especially on slippery surfaces.

questions.question: An underloaded front axle:
questions.answerB: Is encouraged as front axles are usually less strong than other axles.
questions.answerC: Is discouraged as it can cause steering problems.
questions.answerD: Is discouraged as it can improve fuel efficiency.
questions.explanation: Underloading a front axle may make it impossible to safely steer your vehicle. Keep weight distribution in mind when loading cargo.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal:
questions.explanation: When stopping, the brake pedal should be pushed down gradually. Control the pressure so your vehicle comes to a slow, safe stop.

questions.question: While driving, gauges are:
questions.answerC: To be monitored for potential signs of trouble.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should watch your vehicle's gauges for signs of trouble. Be sure to inspect your gauges before beginning a trip to ensure that they are in proper working order.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it could cause the wheels to lock.
questions.answerC: You should turn the wheel very sharply.
questions.answerD: You should hold down the brakes until you are past the hazard.
questions.explanation: If you are turning to avoid a hazard, do not apply the brakes while you are turning. This could easily lock the wheels and create a skid.

questions.question: If a load is 10 feet long, it should be secured by a minimum of:
questions.explanation: Cargo should be restrained by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. However, all cargo should have at least two tie-downs, no matter the size of the cargo.

questions.question: When doing an inspection, make sure your brake pads are:
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: When pulled off on the side of the road:
questions.answerA: A driver should keep the driver’s side door open.
questions.answerB: A driver should turn on the emergency flashers.
questions.answerC: The driver should wave their arms.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, make sure to use your four-way emergency flashers. This is particularly important at night.

questions.question: When driving, being aware of what is happening behind you is:
questions.explanation: When driving, it is important to be aware of what is happening behind and to the sides of your vehicle. Mirror checks and head checks should be a normal part of your scanning routine.

questions.question: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, a person must be:
questions.answerA: A U.S. citizen or permanent resident.
questions.explanation: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you must be a U.S. citizen or lawful permanent resident. You will lose your hazardous materials endorsement if you renounce your U.S. citizenship.

questions.question: In very hot weather, the air pressure in tires may decrease.
questions.explanation: Air expands as its temperature increases, so air pressure in your tires is likely to increase when you are driving in very hot weather. Under such conditions, stop periodically to ensure that your tires are not at risk of blowing out or catching fire.

questions.question: What eliminates alcohol from the bloodstream?
questions.explanation: The body processes alcohol at a fixed rate that cannot be sped up through tricks like drinking coffee. The only way to sober up is to give the body the time it needs to remove the alcohol on its own.

questions.question: Cargo on flatbed trailers should be:
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers or trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down to prevent it from shifting or falling off in transit.

questions.question: Why do large vehicles use air brakes?
questions.answerA: Other brake systems squeak too loudly.
questions.answerB: Air braking systems are very effective.
questions.explanation: Air brakes are an effective and safe way of stopping large and heavy vehicles, as long as they are maintained and used properly.

questions.question: Excessive vibration may be a sign of tire failure.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle thumps or vibrates heavily, it may indicate that a tire has failed. Check your tires as soon as you can safely leave the road.

questions.question: Header boards:
questions.answerB: Protect the driver from being hit by cargo.
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect the driver from cargo moving in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: You should not use your mirrors.
questions.answerC: You should not use your turn signals.
questions.explanation: Always use your turn signals and check your mirrors when changing lanes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a strategy to avoid becoming an aggressive driver?
questions.answerA: Not expecting delays on a drive
questions.answerC: Keeping your hands on the wheel
questions.explanation: Strategies to avoid becoming an aggressive driver include having realistic expectations about your travel time and the possibility of delays; driving an appropriate speed and keeping a reasonable following distance; avoiding gesturing at other drivers; and keeping your hands on the wheel.

questions.question: Of the following, which is the most slippery surface?
questions.explanation: Ice becomes wet when the weather is just warm enough to melt the ice slightly. Wet ice is much more slippery than ice that is not wet.

questions.question: When checking your tires during a pre-trip inspection, you should look for all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires for problems, you should check for air pressure that is too low or too high, cuts or other damage on the tires, and mismatched tire sizes.

questions.question: If equipped, a header board should:
questions.answerC: Be strong enough to contain cargo.
questions.answerD: Light up when the engine is started.
questions.explanation: When checking a header board during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that it is secure, free of damage, and strong enough to contain cargo.

questions.question: When driving on a long downhill slope, you should brake by:
questions.answerB: Mostly using the brakes and occasionally downshifting.
questions.answerC: Downshifting and then using the brakes.
questions.explanation: When approaching a long downgrade, you should shift into a lower gear then use proper braking techniques. Using the brakes alone could cause them to overheat and fail. The braking power of the engine, which is maximized by being in a lower gear, will be the principal way of controlling your speed on a downgrade.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, it is advisable to open up the space in front of your vehicle, making it easier for the tailgater to get around you. Speeding up may be counterproductive because the driver may continue to tailgate you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: A stopped bus:
questions.answerA: Is not a cause for concern.
questions.answerB: Is not a concern if passengers are not unloading.
questions.answerC: Should not be on the roadway.
questions.answerD: Is a concern, whether passengers are visible or not.
questions.explanation: Always drive cautiously around a stopped bus. Passengers may cross in front of or behind it, and the bus may prevent them from seeing your vehicle.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) will:
questions.answerB: Not change the way you apply the brakes.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is in place as an addition to a braking system. It intervenes to prevent brakes from locking up during hard braking. When driving a vehicle with ABS, you should brake in the same way that you would in a vehicle without ABS. It will not necessarily shorten your stopping distance.

questions.question: Using an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. While it provides better control, it does not necessarily shorten a vehicle's stopping distance.

questions.question: Placards should be used:
questions.answerA: Any time a vehicle is carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: If there is open space in the truck.
questions.answerC: If the amount of hazardous materials in the truck exceeds 200 pounds.
questions.answerD: If the hazardous materials create an inhalation hazard.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the outside of vehicles carrying hazardous materials. They identify the specific class or classes of materials being carried and warn others of relevant hazards.

questions.question: Drivers often tailgate trucks in bad weather.
questions.explanation: It is common for automobile drivers to follow too closely behind large trucks in bad weather, especially when it is difficult to see down the road. Safely respond to the tailgater instead of reacting by increasing your speed.

questions.question: Which part of the truck is the air compressor connected to?
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor is connected to the engine through gears or a v-belt.

questions.question: If driving so slowly that you could impede other drivers, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using your four-way flashers.
questions.answerC: Wave an arm out the window.
questions.explanation: If you must drive so slowly that you will impede the flow of traffic, you should turn on your four-way flashers to alert drivers behind you (as long as local laws allow the use of flashers).

questions.question: Air brakes use ____ to function.
questions.explanation: The brakes in an air brake system use compressed air to function properly.

questions.question: Which of the following can help you determine when to upshift?
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Cannot be used on vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can help drivers see a larger area.
questions.explanation: Many large vehicles have curved, convex mirrors. Convex mirrors allow drivers to see a wider area than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they really are.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, what is considered an encroachment?
questions.answerA: The vehicle crossing over an exercise boundary line.
questions.answerB: A driver executing a single pull-up.
questions.answerC: A driver placing the vehicle in neutral and applying the parking brake.
questions.answerD: The vehicle stalling while the driver shifts gears.
questions.explanation: An encroachment during the basic vehicle control skills test is when an exercise boundary line is touched or crossed by any portion of the applicant's vehicle. Every encroachment will be counted as an error.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, what is considered an encroachment?
questions.answerA: A driver placing the vehicle in neutral and applying the parking brake.
questions.answerB: The vehicle touching an exercise boundary line.
questions.answerC: A driver properly completing an exercise in the skills test.
questions.answerD: An applicant trying to bribe the examiner.
questions.explanation: An encroachment during the basic vehicle control skills test is when an exercise boundary line is touched or crossed by any portion of the applicant's vehicle. Every encroachment will be counted as an error.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving, but have the brakes repaired within a week.
questions.answerB: Pull over and inspect the brakes.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should immediately bring the vehicle to a safe stop while you are still able to control the brakes. Inspect and repair the brakes as soon as possible.

questions.question: What happens when a vehicle hydroplanes?
questions.answerA: The tires lose contact with the road.
questions.answerC: The vehicle is easier to control.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning occurs when a vehicle's tires lose contact with the road surface and instead glide along on a film of water above the surface of the road.

questions.question: There is no penalty for refusing to undergo blood alcohol testing.
questions.explanation: Minnesota has an Implied Consent Law, which means that by operating a vehicle in the state, you are understood to have consented to a chemical test if authorities ask you for one. If you refuse to submit to a test, you will be disqualified from operating a CMV for one year and your driver license will be revoked for one year.

questions.question: If a CMV driver operates a CMV with a detectable blood alcohol concentration (BAC) that is lower than 0.04 percent, they will be:
questions.answerC: Required to drive at speeds below 55 mph.
questions.explanation: If you are found to be operating a CMV with any detectable amount of alcohol in your system, but you are still below the legal limit of 0.04 percent, you will be placed out-of-service for 24 hours. It is both illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: Why do drivers have to inspect their vehicles?
questions.answerA: It is usually a company policy.
questions.answerB: It is usually a local ordinance.
questions.answerC: It is a federal and state law.
questions.answerD: It adds to the amount of time for which they will be paid.
questions.explanation: Federal and state laws require drivers to inspect their vehicles before driving to ensure that they are safe to operate.

questions.question: Header boards:
questions.answerB: Protect the driver from being hit by cargo.
questions.answerC: Protect the driver's head when entering the cab of a truck.
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect the driver from cargo moving in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: How should you check your hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should not move.
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly move toward the floor.
questions.answerC: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly rise.
questions.answerD: Pump the brakes three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should be easy to push to the floor.
questions.explanation: To test hydraulic brakes, you should pump the brake pedal three times, then apply firm pressure to the brake pedal and hold for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak.

questions.question: On low bridges:
questions.answerA: Height warnings must always be posted.
questions.answerB: Height warnings must be posted at least twice.
questions.answerC: Height warnings may be posted, but do not have to be.
questions.explanation: Height warnings are often, but not always, posted on low bridges. If you are unsure if you will be able to clear an overhead object, go slowly.

questions.question: When carrying a wide load, you should:
questions.answerB: Obtain special permits and follow special rules, such as driving during certain hours.
questions.answerC: Honk at other drivers to get them to move from the lane closest to you.
questions.explanation: Over-sized loads require special permits, may be allowed on the roads only at certain times, and may require special warning signs or equipment.

questions.question: When traveling long distances, you should:
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming fatigued on a long trip, you should take a break after every 100 miles or two hours of driving. Driving through the night, or during any other time when you would normally be asleep, raises the danger of fatigue.

questions.question: ____ are the most likely to be affected by strong winds.
questions.explanation: Strong winds can make it difficult for a driver to maintain control of their vehicle. Usually, this is especially true for drivers of lighter CMVs.

questions.question: If an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunctions:
questions.answerB: A yellow lamp will light up on the control panel.
questions.explanation: On a vehicle with ABS, a yellow malfunction lamp on the instrument panel will illuminate to alert you if the braking system is not working.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, once air pressure is lost and the spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: You will be unable to move the vehicle.
questions.answerB: A separate air tank can be used to release the spring brakes for a short period of time.
questions.answerC: You can use the spring brakes to continue driving normally.
questions.answerD: The air tanks will automatically refill to a safe air pressure level.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: In an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerD: Always turn on your flashers to warn other drivers.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the safest option when responding to an emergency while driving. It is usually safer to steer out of the way when attempting to avoid a crash.

questions.question: Accelerating roughly is:
questions.answerC: Discouraged, as it may cause damage to the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Discouraged, as it may confuse other drivers.
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: When starting a CMV, the oil pressure gauge should take about a minute to display a normal pressure level.
questions.explanation: After starting an engine, the oil pressure should rise to a normal range within seconds. If your oil pressure is low, dropping, or fluctuating, you should immediately stop driving.

questions.question: When driving a 50-foot truck at 50 mph, you should maintain a following distance of at least:
questions.explanation: When traveling at speeds below 40 mph, you should maintain at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle's length. At higher speeds, add an additional second.

questions.question: How much water is needed on a road surface for a vehicle to hydroplane?
questions.answerB: A good amount, such as a large puddle
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be much water on the road for this to occur.

questions.question: If a load is 10 feet long, it should be secured by a minimum of:
questions.explanation: Cargo should be restrained by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. However, all cargo should have at least two tie-downs, no matter the size of the cargo.

questions.question: What should be used to check for proper tire inflation?
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must use a tire gauge to check for proper tire inflation. You will not receive passing credit if you simply kick the tires.

questions.question: If you’re not sure what to do to extinguish a fire in your vehicle, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are not sure which kind of extinguisher should be used on a fire in your vehicle, particularly a hazardous materials fire, you should wait for the firefighters to arrive and allow them to extinguish it.

questions.question: You should always be able to stop within:
questions.answerC: Your view of the road ahead.
questions.explanation: You should always make sure that your vehicle will be able to stop within the area of the road that you are able to see. This means that you must slow down whenever conditions reduce visibility.

questions.question: A steering wheel should be held:
questions.answerB: With one hand, keeping the other hand free for other tasks.
questions.answerC: With one hand at a time, alternating between hands.
questions.answerD: At the base of the wheel.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should be held firmly with both hands, positioned on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: If driving so slowly that you could impede other drivers, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using your four-way flashers.
questions.explanation: If you must drive so slowly that you will impede the flow of traffic, you should turn on your four-way flashers to alert drivers behind you (as long as local laws allow the use of flashers).

questions.question: Which of the following is not a crime that would disqualify an applicant from a hazardous materials endorsement?
questions.explanation: There are a number of crimes that will disqualify a person from receiving a hazardous materials endorsement for seven years. Among these are kidnapping or hostage taking, smuggling, and immigration violations. More serious crimes, such as murder, will result in a lifetime disqualification.

questions.question: How can you check hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brake pedal three times then apply firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should not move.
questions.answerB: Pump the brake pedal three times then apply firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should move slowly toward the floor.
questions.answerC: Pump the brake pedal three times then apply firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly rise.
questions.explanation: Check hydraulic brakes by pumping the brake pedal three times before applying firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak or some other problem in the braking system.

questions.question: On a flatbed trailer, a load does not need to be tied down if it is heavy enough.
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and on trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down to prevent it from shifting or falling off in transit. You should be aware of tie-down requirements for your particular cargo.

questions.question: To ensure that you do not slow down traffic when driving a large truck, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to pass another vehicle while driving uphill.
questions.answerC: Stay in the right lane whenever possible.
questions.explanation: If a heavy load prevents your vehicle from keeping up with the speed of other traffic, you should stay in the right lane.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not a recommended way to spot potential signs of trouble?
questions.answerC: Checking critical items only at the beginning and end of a trip
questions.explanation: During a trip, you should regularly make checks to ensure that your vehicle is operating properly. Check the instrument panel and gauges; look at your mirrors; and examine the tires, cargo, and lights. Use all of your senses and be alert for anything that could be an early indication of trouble.

questions.question: If federal inspectors judge your vehicle to be unsafe, they can:
questions.answerA: Bring you to a garage to have your vehicle fixed.
questions.answerB: Formerly request that you have your vehicle's problems fixed.
questions.answerD: Pull the vehicle out-of-service until it is fixed.
questions.explanation: If a federal or state inspector judges a CMV to be unsafe, they may put it out-of-service until it is fixed.

questions.question: If you must stop on the side of a highway, how far behind your vehicle should warning devices be placed?
questions.explanation: When stopping your CMV on the side of a highway, warning devices must be placed 10 feet, 100 feet, and 200 feet behind the vehicle.

questions.question: What does the vehicle inspection report do?
questions.answerA: Inform the motor carrier about problems that may need fixing
questions.answerB: Ensure that the vehicle is inspected regularly
questions.answerC: Keep people accountable for inspecting the vehicle
questions.explanation: A vehicle inspection report keeps the carrier informed about any problems that need to be fixed.

questions.question: When checking tires, finding which of the following is not a cause for concern?
questions.answerB: Tread of at least 4/32 of an inch in the grooves on front tires
questions.answerC: Radial and bias-ply tires used together
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's tires, you should confirm that air pressure is neither too low nor too high; that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires; and that radial and bias-ply tires are not used together.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, a CDL applicant may be asked to:
questions.explanation: While testing for a CDL, an applicant will be required to go through a full vehicle inspection. The vehicle inspection test will include an engine oil level check.

questions.question: Fuel records supporting IFTA quarterly fuel use tax returns must be kept by carriers for:
questions.explanation: In general, if you operate a commercial vehicle in interstate commerce, it must be registered under the International Registration Plan (IRP) and International Fuel Tax Agreement (IFTA). These programs collect and distribute vehicle registration fees and fuel taxes based on what jurisdictions you drive in and for how long. Mileage and fuel records supporting IFTA quarterly fuel tax returns must be retained by carriers for four years.

questions.question: Excessive vibration may be a sign of tire failure.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle thumps or vibrates heavily, it may indicate that a tire has failed. Check your tires as soon as you can safely leave the road.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal should be:
questions.answerA: Pressed down quickly with both feet.
questions.explanation: When braking, push the pedal down gradually to ensure that the vehicle comes to a smooth, safe stop.

questions.question: When completing pre-trip inspections:
questions.answerA: The inspections should be done the same way each time.
questions.answerB: Different items should be checked each time.
questions.answerC: It is acceptable to check items in a different order each time.
questions.answerD: Not every item needs to be inspected each time.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: Front brake limiting valves were intended to:
questions.answerA: Prevent the front tires from skidding.
questions.answerB: Prevent the front tires from overheating.
questions.answerD: Remove uncertainty when applying the brakes.
questions.explanation: Some older vehicles with air brakes have front brake limiting valves. These valves were intended to reduce the risk of front wheels skidding. However, research has shown that such devices are unnecessary, so they should be left in the "normal" position.

questions.question: Texting while driving is:
questions.answerA: Allowed if you are contacting your employer.
questions.answerB: Allowed when driving on rural roads.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is dangerous and is never permitted while operating a CMV.

questions.question: Mirrors should be:
questions.answerC: Checked only if there is a reason to suspect a problem.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should regularly check your mirrors, both to be aware of traffic and to check for problems on your own vehicle.

questions.question: Cargo inside a trailer:
questions.answerA: Does not need to be secured.
questions.answerB: Should be stacked no taller than three feet high.
questions.answerC: Should be secured to prevent movement in transit.
questions.answerD: Should be loaded with the heaviest items on top of lighter items.
questions.explanation: Cargo must be properly secured to prevent it from moving in transit. Loose cargo can be dangerous to the driver operating the CMV, as well as to other road users.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.explanation: If you must drive in fog, you should use your low beam headlights and fog lights, even during the day.

questions.question: When stopping, you should:
questions.answerA: Press down the brake pedal quickly.
questions.answerB: Press down the brake pedal gradually.
questions.answerC: Lift up the brake pedal quickly.
questions.explanation: When stopping, press down the brake pedal smoothly and gradually.

questions.question: An applicant will be denied a hazardous materials endorsement if they:
questions.explanation: Your application for a hazardous materials endorsement can be denied, or your existing endorsement canceled, if you do not have legal permanent status in the United States; you renounce U.S. citizenship; you are wanted for, under indictment for, or convicted of certain felonies; you are judged mentally incompetent or are involuntarily committed to a mental institution; or you are deemed by the Transportation Security Administration to pose a security threat.

questions.question: Which of the following is a sign of a potentially drunk driver?
questions.answerA: They are staying in their traffic lane.
questions.answerB: They are driving a consistent speed.
questions.answerC: They are stopping without a reason.
questions.answerD: They have alcohol-related bumper stickers on their vehicle.
questions.explanation: Warning signs that a driver may be impaired include that they are having trouble staying in their lane, they are having trouble maintaining an appropriate driving speed, or they are stopping without a clear reason.

questions.question: When driving a truck requiring a CDL:
questions.answerA: You do not need to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerB: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if transporting more than 500 pounds of cargo.
questions.answerC: You must always wear a seat belt.
questions.explanation: You must be properly restrained by a safety belt at all times when driving a commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: What helps prevent wheel lockup when braking?
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent wheel lockup while brakes are being applied.

questions.question: When are people usually the least alert?
questions.explanation: Most drivers are the least alert at night, especially after midnight. Therefore, crashes due to fatigued driving are more likely at night than any other time of day.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance to:
questions.answerA: Check the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerC: See if rocks have gotten into the tread.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop a short distance later to recheck the tightness of the tire's lug nuts.

questions.question: Where is the safety relief valve usually located?
questions.explanation: An air brake system's safety relief valve is located in the tank that is first to receive air from the compressor.

questions.question: If making a tight turn, the operator of a CMV should:
questions.answerA: Be able to drive as fast as the driver of a car.
questions.answerB: Not be concerned about speed, but focus on the road.
questions.answerC: Warn drivers behind by braking early and slowing gradually.
questions.explanation: Drivers behind you may not anticipate how slowly your CMV must travel to safely make a right turn. You can help warn them in advance by braking early and slowing gradually.

questions.question: If you doubt that you have enough space to safely drive under a bridge or sign, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are not certain that your vehicle will fit under overhead objects, you should slow down and take a different route, if possible.

questions.question: Before attempting to put out an engine fire:
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The accelerator should be depressed to use up the remaining fuel.
questions.explanation: If you experience an engine fire, you should turn off the engine as soon as safely possible. Avoid opening the vehicle's hood when extinguishing the fire.

questions.question: As the driver of a truck carrying a load, you are responsible for all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Knowing the phone numbers of all fire departments along your intended route of travel.
questions.explanation: It is the driver's responsibility to inspect their cargo; recognize overloading or poorly balanced weight; know that the cargo is properly secured and does not obscure the driver's view; and know that the cargo does not restrict access to emergency equipment. The driver is responsible for their cargo even if they were not the one who initially loaded and secured the cargo.

questions.question: To check the automatic transmission fluid level in some vehicles, the vehicle:
questions.answerD: May have to be left running.
questions.explanation: For some vehicles, you may need to leave the engine running to be able to check its automatic transmission fluid level.

questions.question: When stopping in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Veer your trailer to the right and stop.
questions.answerC: Veer your trailer to the left and stop.
questions.explanation: If you need to make an emergency stop, you can use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method. It's important to brake in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line but will still allow you to turn if necessary.

questions.question: Driving at a consistent speed for a long period of time could be a sign of distracted driving.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is traveling at inconsistent speeds, it could be an indication that the driver is distracted. Give distracted drivers plenty of space on the road.

questions.question: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, a person must be:
questions.answerA: A U.S. citizen or permanent resident.
questions.explanation: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you must be a U.S. citizen or lawful permanent resident. You will lose your hazardous materials endorsement if you renounce your U.S. citizenship.

questions.question: When changing lanes, turn signals:
questions.answerB: Should only be used if a vehicle is close to you.
questions.explanation: Always signal your intentions before turning or changing lanes. Do not assume that other drivers will move out of your way simply because you are signaling to turn.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it could cause the wheels to lock.
questions.answerC: You should turn the wheel very sharply.
questions.answerD: You should hold down the brakes until you are past the hazard.
questions.explanation: If you are turning to avoid a hazard, do not apply the brakes while you are turning. This could easily lock the wheels and create a skid.

questions.question: Noting the speed of other vehicles is one way to determine when to upshift.
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: A cardboard box on the road:
questions.answerB: Should be avoided by driving off the roadway.
questions.explanation: Any foreign object on the road is potentially dangerous. For example, something seemingly harmless, such as a cardboard box or paper sack, could contain a hard or heavy object that could do serious damage to a vehicle.

questions.question: If you are braking on dry pavement while traveling at 55 mph, how much distance will brake lag add to your overall stopping distance?
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to the vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: In an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerD: Always turn on your flashers to warn other drivers.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the safest option when responding to an emergency while driving. It is usually safer to steer out of the way when attempting to avoid a crash.

questions.question: What is brake lag?
questions.answerA: The time required for the brakes to work after the brake pedal is pushed
questions.answerB: The distance between the brake pedal’s resting position and the floor
questions.answerC: The amount of air pressure used to stop a vehicle
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work. On vehicles with hydraulic brakes, the brakes work instantly when the pedal is pressed.

questions.question: Items on a flatbed:
questions.answerA: Are usually heavy enough to not need to be strapped down.
questions.answerB: Should not be strapped down if you are driving more slowly than 35 mph.
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down to prevent it from shifting or falling off in transit.

questions.question: A ramp's posted speed limit:
questions.answerB: Is suitable for some vehicles, but may be too fast for a large CMV.
questions.answerC: Is just a suggestion and may be exceeded.
questions.explanation: Posted speed limits on exit and entrance ramps often show speeds that are safe to be driven by cars. However, these speed limits may be too fast for large or heavily-loaded vehicles and CMV drivers will likely need to slow down to a speed below the posted limit.

questions.question: Blocking a load:
questions.answerA: Is dangerous and should never be done.
questions.answerC: Is only done with liquid cargo.
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are used to prevent cargo from shifting in transit.

questions.question: When approaching a vehicle for a pre-trip inspection, a driver should look under the vehicle:
questions.answerA: To see if the vehicle is on an incline.
questions.answerB: To see if there are any fresh fluids under the vehicle.
questions.answerC: To see if the vehicle is in a parking spot.
questions.answerD: To see if the vehicle is on a decline.
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle to conduct an inspection, you should look underneath it to make sure there are no fresh oil, coolant, grease, or fuel leaks on the ground. Leaks can indicate unsafe defects on a vehicle.

questions.question: When using a fire extinguisher on a fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Get as close to the fire as possible.
questions.answerB: Stand as far away from the fire as possible.
questions.answerC: Aim the extinguisher at the top of the fire.
questions.explanation: When using a fire extinguisher, you should stand as far away from the fire as possible. Aim the extinguisher at the base of the fire, not at the flames. If you are not sure which kind of extinguisher should be used on a fire, particularly a hazardous materials fire, you should wait for the firefighters to arrive and allow them to extinguish it.

questions.question: Bridges usually:
questions.answerA: Freeze, but only once the temperature drops significantly below 32 degrees Fahrenheit.
questions.answerB: Freeze after other road surfaces freeze.
questions.answerD: Have heaters to prevent them from freezing.
questions.explanation: Bridges usually freeze before the rest of the road. You should be especially careful when crossing bridges if the temperature is near the freezing point.

questions.question: If a vehicle has a vehicle inspection report, the driver:
questions.answerA: Should not look at the report and instead try to find any issues themselves.
questions.answerB: Should take the vehicle to a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and rely only on the report.
questions.explanation: For the first step of a vehicle inspection, you should review the last inspection report on your vehicle, if there is one. The carrier should have repaired any problems noted on the report.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, you should:
questions.answerA: Place as little weight as possible over the axles.
questions.answerB: Place a well-balanced amount of weight over the axles.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with how the weight is distributed.
questions.explanation: A load of cargo must be properly balanced. Placing too much weight over an axle can damage the axle and make it more difficult for you to steer. Placing too little weight over an axle can cause poor traction, also leading to difficult handling.

questions.question: Emergency equipment, such as a fire extinguisher, is:
questions.answerA: Only needed for vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: To prevent fatigue while driving, you should:
questions.explanation: A hot, poorly-ventilated area can make a person sleepy. Opening a window, opening a vent, or using the air conditioning can help keep the cab cool and reduce the risk of fatigue.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection:
questions.answerA: Should never be completed the same way two times in a row.
questions.answerB: Should always be completed in the same order.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if it is sunny outside.
questions.answerD: Should not be done if the driver thinks the vehicle is in good operating order.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip inspection should be completed in the same way before every drive. Consistency will help you learn all of the proper steps and decrease the likelihood that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: A high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Makes a vehicle more susceptible to rollover.
questions.explanation: A high center of gravity makes a vehicle more likely to tip over.

questions.question: When you press the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air pressure pushes out the rod and moves the:
questions.explanation: When pressing the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air will enter the brake chambers. The added air pressure will push out the rods and move slack adjusters, twisting the brake camshafts.

questions.question: Distracted drivers may be:
questions.answerC: Preoccupied with using their cell phones.
questions.answerD: Not talking to anyone else in their vehicles.
questions.explanation: You may be able to tell that another driver is distracted if you can see them drifting within a lane or across lane dividers; traveling at inconsistent speeds; being preoccupied with a cell phone, a map, food, or other items; or engaging in conversation with passengers.

questions.question: Retreaded tires:
questions.answerA: May be used on any part of a bus.
questions.answerB: May be used on the front of a bus.
questions.answerC: May be used on the rear of a bus.
questions.answerD: May never be used on a bus.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are prohibited from use on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: When checking the exhaust system, it should be:
questions.explanation: When checking the exhaust system, you should verify that no parts of the system are loose, broken, or missing.

questions.question: Where can you find the tire load rating?
questions.answerA: On the inside of the driver’s door
questions.answerC: On the side of each tire
questions.explanation: A tire load rating is the maximum safe weight that can be carried by a tire at a specified pressure. This number is stated on the side of each tire.

questions.question: What should a driver do if their vehicle hydroplanes?
questions.answerC: Release the accelerator and push in the clutch.
questions.answerD: Take the vehicle out of gear.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, you should slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch.

questions.question: Air pressure should build up in a single air system within:
questions.explanation: In single air systems, air pressure should build from approximately 50 to 90 psi within three minutes.

questions.question: What kind of force do emergency brakes use?
questions.explanation: Air brakes are really three different braking systems: the service brake, the parking brake, and the emergency brake. Emergency and parking brakes are applied with mechanical force.

questions.question: Which of the following is true?
questions.answerA: It is safe to drive on a tire that is missing one or two lug nuts.
questions.answerB: A cracked lock ring on a rim is safe if you are not driving faster than 55 mph.
questions.answerC: A missing clamp on a rim is dangerous and should be corrected.
questions.explanation: Missing clamps, spacers, studs, or lugs are dangerous, as are mismatched, bent, or cracked lock rings. Be sure your tires and rims are in good condition before operating your commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: How long should it take for oil pressure to reach a normal level when starting a vehicle?
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the oil pressure should come up to a normal level within seconds. Do not operate a vehicle if it has oil pressure that is low, dropping, or fluctuating.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.answerD: Travel faster than the speed limit.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should always scan the road for potential hazards. Formulate plans for how to deal with the hazards if they develop into emergencies.

questions.question: Poor weight balance:
questions.answerC: Increases a driver’s ability to steer.
questions.explanation: Poorly balanced loads can lead to unsafe handling. It is important to properly distribute the weight of cargo when loading a vehicle.

questions.question: The minimum age you must be to apply for a CDL is 21.
questions.explanation: You must be at least 18 years old to apply for a CDL. However, you must be at least 21 years old to drive in interstate commerce, as well as to have a hazardous materials, passenger, or school bus endorsement.

questions.question: When checking the exhaust system, it should be:
questions.explanation: When checking the exhaust system, you should verify that no parts of the system are loose, broken, or missing.

questions.question: When traveling down a hill, you can reduce the amount of required braking by:
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, decelerate and shift down into a gear that will allow you to control your vehicle without braking too hard. Using too much brake when driving downhill can cause the brakes to overheat, reducing the braking power.

questions.question: A broken exhaust system can:
questions.answerA: Let poisonous fumes into the cab.
questions.explanation: Defects in an exhaust system are very dangerous because they can cause poisonous fumes to enter the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the driver.
